speaker: Facebook posts
vclaim: He says that "children's bones" were found on Jeffrey Epstein's island.
date: stated on August 22, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, "the bones of the children " were not discovered on Geoffrey Epstein's private island
text: Soon after Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in a cell in Manhattan in August 2019, a rush of conspiracy theories spread over the Internet. Another disturbing theory now appeared on Facebook: children's bones were found on Epstein's private island. The island, the small St. James, is part of the United States Virgin Islands and has reportedly been named "Children's Island" and "Orgie's Island" by the local population. This article, which has received over 4,500 shares since August 22, says: "The children's bones were found on Epstein Island. My question? Why isn't this in the headlines of every major network?" The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) On January 10, 2021, in an article on Facebook, he said that Nancy Belusi had sent a letter to the mayor of Portland after demonstrations there "requiring him to stick to a proven democratic playbook." By Sira Aurourke on January 11, 2021, and as is customary with artificial Internet conspiracy theories, the important discovery was not in the headlines of the "EVERY" news network because it did not happen. The false rumours have been published on many other viral social media sites, and appear to have arisen in an article on 13 August published through the conspiracy website of what is duetmian.com. The title of that article? "FBI Divers recovers human bones in the water off Epstein's island of Urgia with 'State Deb' accelerating Miltdown." It is well known that the Sorsha Fall website disseminates misleading information by including existing parts of legitimate news in their stories (in this case by writing that Epstein owned an island and that the FBI raided the building) and then uses this as a basis for building gruesome fictions, claiming that he was the first to break the story without reliable sources. A group of FBI investigators raided Epstein Island on August 12, but there were no reports of human bones anywhere, including under the "Epstein Demon Temple," as the article claims. News organizations around the world have submitted very extensive and detailed reports on the Epstein case, and therefore the fact that no reliable media outlets have disclosed any of this information indicates that it is fabricated. We're assessing this statement wrong.
